Description: Shoulder sherd of Clazomenian black-figured pottery amphora; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of bridled horse to right (part of head, neck with stud in added white on bridle and mane remaining).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

For a parallel, see Athens 12713, Cook 1952, pl.31,1 and Boardman, J., Early Greek Vase Painting. London 1998, 171, fig. 348. The sherd possibly belongs to the same vessel as Oxford AN1896-1908-G.130.5. The fabric of the sherd was analysed by the Research Laboratory for Archaeology at Oxford. Ward's Method Cluster Analysis (WMCA) and Principal Components Analysis (PCA) found great similarities with the fabric from Wild Goat Style sherds found at Bayrakli in Asia Minor, production of which Dupont had attributed to Clazomenae. Based on the similar composition types, Dupont then suggested that the place of production for this sherd ought to be situated near Clazomenae, Erythrae, or Teos (Jones with J. Boardman in Jones 1986, p.664).
Bibliographic references: Cook 1952 / A List of Clazomenian Pottery (p. 136, no. 2)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 87, pl.X, no.3)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GH.039) (Phase 1)
Jones 1986 / Greek and Cypriot Pottery: a Review of Scientific Studies (p.701, table 8.18, no.27)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
